captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
-(SINGING) And this is my wish.

-12-year-old Kevin Lee
of Farmington Hills,

Michigan plays violin in the
orchestra at his middle school.

It's an activity in which
he can participate fully.

More rough and tumble fun
poses a serious threat.

-Because I have this
heart surgery thing.

And it kind of stops
me from doing stuff.

Something could go wrong,
and I could just die.

-It was just moments
after his birth
when doctors whisked Kevin away.

-They found out that
his right ventricle
didn't form when he was born.

And that he was probably
not going to see six months.
The whole world stopped.

My heart just dropped
out of my stomach.
It was terrible.

-Kevin underwent his
first heart surgery
when he was three days old.

He spent his first month
hooked up to a ventilator.
-I just wanted to hold him.

I just wanted to pick
him up and love him.

And I couldn't even
touch my own child.

-What did you say to
him when you held him
for the first time?
-I love you.
And it's going to be OK.

-Kevin's had three
more surgeries

since and some frantic
trips to the ER.

His heart remains susceptible to
a chest impact or overexertion.
-I'm running around and stuff.

And I just stop and
see how it feels.

Sometimes, it feels
like a sword's

going through your
chest or something.

-He's still at a high
risk for sudden death.
So it's every day.
-Kevin's parents are divorced.

His father Doug lives in the
Middle Eastern nation of Qatar,

and returns to
visit once a year.

Sports is a big
part of their bond.

-I think that his
dad not being here,

that this was one thing
that they share is football.

That's something that him and
his dad have always shared.
-Hut!

-Kevin is expecting
a visit this fall.

And being with his dad
is part of his wish,

to meet his favorite player,
Russell Wilson, and the Seattle
Seahawks.

-So if somebody told you
you could have your wish,

I don't know, like tomorrow,
what would you say?

-I would say it's
going to have to wait.

Because I ain't doing
it without my dad here.
-The number 75--

-When Kevin and his extended
family want some Russell Wilson
highlights--

-Are you ignoring me
because football's on?
-Mhmm.

-They're not expecting to
see a message from Coach Pete
Carroll.

-Hey Kevin, this
is Pete Carroll.

I'm the coach at
Seattle Seahawks.

We want to extend an
invitation to you.

I know that you've been battling
and competing like crazy,

and we would love for you to
come out here and visit us.

The Seahawks are practicing,
and you can come and bring
your family with you.

And I want to make sure
you know that we're

going to send you a
little package here.
Good luck.
I'll see you later.
Go Seahawks.
-Did you hear that?

-The coach's invitation leaves
the family ecstatic for Kevin.

But his reaction is
a little bit muted.
-Why are you mad?

Is there a part of your
wish that's missing?
[DOORBELL RINGS]

-Downstairs, hidden behind a
wind blown array of balloons,

is someone who has
traveled some 7,000
miles to be here on this day.
-This is for you.
Hey, buddy.
How you doing?
I love you too, buddy.

-He's been through
more than I'll ever

be through in my
whole entire life.

That's why, to this day,
I call him Superman.
-It's good to see you.
-Let's go Seahawks!

-Days later, Kevin
and family roll up

to the Seahawks
training camp, where
a big time welcome awakes.
-Oh my god.
That's for you.
-With cheerleaders--
-How are you?
Can I get a high five?
-And the Seahawks drum line.

He gets a welcome from Coach
Carroll and GM John Schneider.
-Congratulations, Kevin.
You're part of the Seahawks.

-Who signs Kevin to
a five year deal.

-What do you think of the
contract, first of all?
Do you like it?
-Sort of.

I would like six years, but
you know, if they want five,
they can do that.

-The newest Seahawk
makes a bold prediction.
-I can tell you one thing.
-OK.
-One thing.

There will be a
Super Bowl this year.
-Kevin, Kevin, Kevin, Kevin.

-They're chanting his name
as Kevin makes his way

to the equipment room, smiling,
high fiving, and giving
autographs.
-You're so cool, Kevin.
-There we go.

-He gets a helmet,
and his ankles taped.
-Are you fast?
-Yes.
-Yeah.
I could tell.
That's why I used the fast tape.

-Kevin and his dad check
out practice for a bit.
Here comes Russell Wilson.
-What's up, Bud?
How you doing, man?
Nice jersey you got on.
-Thanks.
-Come on, come with me.
I'll show you something cool.
Keep them eyes closed.
You ready?
Open your eyes.
-Whoa.
-You got your own locker, man.
What you think?

-After posing for
photos, these two

head off to lunch, where
Kevin's come prepared

with a notebook full of
interesting questions

for Russell and
receiver Golden Tate.
-I do hate losing.

That is one thing
I very much hate.

Can you give me any advice on
how to handle it and stuff?

-I think the biggest
thing about losing

is being humble about it, not
being a sore loser in terms

of trying to learn from
my wins, and trying
to learn from my losses.

-I'd say the biggest thing
is just don't show it.
Be strong about it.

Try to come back and have your
best week of practice ever.

-On the way back to practice,
All-Pro cornerback Richard
Sherman gets Kevin fired up.
-You ready, Kevin?
-Sure.

-See, no, that's
not enthusiastic.

Are you ready to
tell [INAUDIBLE]?
-Yeah!
-That's what I'm talking about.

-As the players take
the field, Kevin

joins them for stretching
and some drills.
-Pick your feet up. [INAUDIBLE].

Put your hands behind
your head, like this.
There it is.
-Go a little back and see.
There you go.

-Pete Carroll checks out
his new player's potential.

Finally, the boy who
doesn't always get to play

back home takes the field
here with Russell Wilson,

and shows off his
quarterback arm.
-Nice throw.
-Hut!

-If you run up five
yards and run out,
look around the out route.

And then go up, right in
between the two of them, OK?
-It's a touchdown.

And his touchdown dance
gets the whole team going.
-Good to see you, buddy.
See you, buddy.
I'll see you, OK?

-On his way out,
Kevin sees his name

on the Seahawks All
Time roster, a fitting
ending to his special day.

title: My Wish: Seattle Seahawks Grant Kevin Lee's Wish

comments.author: Michael Green

comments.text:
Sam Chew wants to know:

BuckSTONE Cooper III, is that you? What about Charlie Wilston?

On the same night: Venus Flytrap (Tim Reid) gave an impromptu atom lesson 
and Cora Isley played station cleaning lady, Veronica Redd, with Keny Long 
as her delinquent son, Arnold Isley (Keny Long), who briefly becomes 
Flytrap's pupil in the "Venus and the Man" ep. of "WKRP in Cincinnati".

Don't Sleep on This:

Unrelated to Cora Isley as WKRP cleaning lady Veronica Redd in the ep., 
consider Cincinnati-born Russell Wilson turned 19 years old on 11/29/07—the 
same day Sebastian soZZi was janitor Benjy Alvarado, who had mop duty in 
the locker room of the Newell Knights college football team. Benjy's 
girlfriend, Carla Sanchez (Elena Hurst) had falsely accused team members of 
sexual assault. The father of one accused player, wheelchair-bound Curtis 
Pardue (Gil DEEble), had played professional football, but was left 
paralyzed by a gunshot wound after he tried to defend a woman he didn't 
know outside a nightclub. The ep. guest starred 1980s cinema "Brat Pack" 
member Andrew McCarthy as A.D.A. Gene Hoyle.

McCarthy (spouse: Dolores Rice--m. 2011), like Russell Wilson, also had a 
birthday on 11/29/07, turning 45 years old.

Unrelated: Wilson playing football for one season for the University of 
Wisconsin Badgers football team in a state that counts among its historic 
politicians, communist witch-hunting U.S. Senator, Joseph RAYmond McCarthy.

Note: Tim "Save Our Streets" Reid (b. 12/19/44 in Norfolk, VA) graduated 
Norfolk State Univ., where Russell Wilson's granddaddy, Dr. Harrison B. 
Wilson, would become president for two decades ending in the late 1990s. 
After "WKRP", Reid starred with the identical twin MOWry sisters in sitcom 
"Sister, Sister", playing limousine service proprietor—and one of the 
twins' adoptive father—RAYmond Earl "RAY" Campbell. The show also starred 
Winston-Salem, NC-born Jackée Harry (b. 8/14/56) as the other twin's 
adoptive mother, Lisa Landry Sims.

Unrelated: Firsts involving HBCU football in the 1987 season

Unrelated to Nazis:

The 7/6/78 GERMAN-born MOWry twins are Tia DASHon MOWry and Tamera Darvette 
MOWry-HOUSley. Tamera married FOX News correspondent Arthur Adam HOUSley 
(b. 8/13/72). Tia’s husband is actor Cory HARDrict, who guest starred as 
Tony the Cable guy in the "Hill Street Blues"(2009) and "Truth and 
Consequences (2009)" eps. of his wife’s pro-football themed drama series, 
“The Game”. Tia plays Melanie Barnett in the show—the first cousin of Joan 
Clayton, parent sitcom Girlfriends' principal character.

Unrelated: Joan Clayton  in “Girlfriends” played by Tracee Ellis Ross (b. 
10/29/72), who in 2014 starred in freshman ABC sitcom “Black-ish”, playing 
Rainbow Johnson.

Unrelated: U.S. Senate politics in 2013 and 2014. Still, Cory D. (Dezanard) 
HARDrict spells his first name with the same “skipping E” bastardization of 
traditional “CorEy” as U.S. Senator Cory A. Booker (D-NJ)—the least tenured 
member of the Senate after winning a special election in October 2013. In 
2013, Booker was running to fill the unexpired term of fellow Democrat 
Frank Raleigh Lautenberg, who died on June 3. In 2014, Booker is running 
again for the seat and the full six-year term, in the regularly scheduled 
election.

Curiously, Booker was sworn into the Senate on 10/31/13—Halloween for 
pagans—tweeting to his Twitter followers that for the ceremony, he used the 
same bible given to him by his family, on which he had taken the oath of 
office for Newark, NJ mayor in 2006. The previous day, U.S. Rep. Cory Scott 
Gardner (b. 8/22/74)—who also has the “skipping E” version of traditional 
“CorEy”—made headlines for his toughest on the House Energy and Commerce 
Committee grilling of Health and Human Services Secretary, Kathleen 
Sebelius. Sebelius was testifying before the committee over the disastrous 
debut of the government’s internet website enrolling customers into the 
Affordable Care Act—the implementation of which, Sebelius’ department was 
directly responsible. Photos of Gardner and Sebelius at the hearing were 
credited to Associated Press photographer J. Scott Applewhite.

Republican Cory Gardner, like Democrat Cory Booker, is seeking election to 
the U.S. Senate in 2014. Gardner’s race in Colorado against incumbent MARK 
UdALL could evoke Sebastian soZZi as college football locker room janitor 
Benjy Alvarado. Especially so when considering Booker’s past playing tight 
end for the Stanford University Cardinal football team in the late 1980s 
and early 1990s, and Gardner’s Senate race encountering controversy over 
whether he made the varsity or junior varsity squad at his high school alma 
mater.

The confusion over Gardner’s high school football career at Yuma High 
School (Yuma, CO) was cleared up by Chuck Pflamer—a teacher who served as 
the team’s statistician and remembered that Gardner had played three years 
in total, with his junior year “on varsity”.

Nevertheless, as a person who attended high school concurrently with Booker 
and Gardner, I can only imagine Gardner’s football “controversy” might be 
the result of COLLEGE vs. HIGH SCHOOL social order projections.

Note: Gardner won his U.S. House seat representing Colorado’s 4th 
congressional district by beating incumbent Elizabeth Helen “BETsy” MARKey 
in the 2010 midterm election. While Cory Booker represents New Jersey in 
the Senate, MARKey was born in Cresskill, NJ and turned 13 years old on the 
day Booker was born in Washington D.C.—4/27/69.

Notably, Booker’s 2013 special election opponent, Steven Mark "Steve" 
Lonegan, served as the former mayor of Bogota, NJ and was born the very 
same day as MARKey—4/27/56.

Start the countdown: Unrelated to the 321 telephone area code for NASA at 
Cape Canaveral, public directories show a Charles E. Pfalmer at 321 E. 10th 
Ave., Yuma, CO 80759-3001﻿
comments.author: GWhiz99

same bible given him by his family that he had taken the oath of office for 
Newark, NJ mayor on in 2006. The previous day, U.S. Rep. Cory Scott Gardner 
(b. 8/22/74)—who also has the “skipping E” version of traditional “CorEy”, 
made headlines for his toughest on the House Energy and Commerce Committee 
grilling of Health and Human Services Secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, over 
the disastrous debut of the government’s internet website enrolling 
customers into the Affordable Care Act—the implementation of which, 
Sebelius’ department was directly responsible. Photos of the meeting were 
credited to Associated Press photographer J. Scott Applewhite.

Republican Cory Gardner, like Booker, is seeking election to the U.S. 
Senate in 2014. Gardner’s race in Colorado against incumbent MARK UdALL 
could evoke Sebastian soZZi as college football locker room janitor Benjy 
Alvarado. Especially considering Booker’s past playing tight end for the 
Stanford University Cardinal football team in the late 1980s and early 
1990s, and Gardner’s Senate race encountering controversy over whether he 
made the varsity or junior varsity squad at his high school alma mater.

As a person who attended high school concurrently with Booker and Gardner, 
I can only imagine Gardner’s football “controversy” could be the result of 
COLLEGE vs. HIGH SCHOOL social order projections. Nevertheless, the 
confusion over Gardner’s high school football career at Yuma High School 
(Yuma, CO) was cleared up by Chuck Pflamer—a teacher who served as the 
team’s statistician and remembered that Gardner had played three years in 
total, with his junior year “on varsity”.

Note: Gardner won his seat representing Colorado’s 4th congressional 
district by beating incumbent Elizabeth Helen “BETsy” MARKey in the 2010 
midterm election. While Cory Booker represents New Jersey in the Senate, 
MARKey was born in Cresskill, NJ and turned 13 years old on the day Booker 
was born in Washington D.C.—4/27/69. Notably, Booker’s 2013 special 
election opponent, Steven Mark "Steve" Lonegan, served as the former mayor 
of Bogota, NJ and was born the very same day as MARKey—4/27/56.

Start the countdown: Unrelated to the 321 telephone area code for NASA at 
Cape Canaveral, public directories show a Charles E. Pfalmer at 321 E. 10th 
Ave., Yuma, CO 80759-3001﻿
